section.title: Audience
section.para: CentOS Studio is a product intended for system administrators who need to build, test, deploy and maintain Red Hat Enterprise Linux or CentOS-based systems. Certain chapters in this manual assume you have a particular level of knowledge.

For Chapter 3, "Building a System," in addition to knowing how to create and edit XML files, manage a web server and create USB and CD/DVD boot media, you should have an intermediate skill level with the following components:

listitem.para: Red Hat Enterprise Linux or CentOS installation, usage, system administration and configuration;
RPM package usage; and
YUM usage and configuration.

section.para: For Chapter 4, "Creating a Production Environment," experience with version control systems, local mirror hosting, XPath and XInclude.
For Chapter 5, "Doing More with CentOS Studio," key skills include understanding how to automate Anaconda installations using kickstart files and command line arguments.

section.title: What's Not Covered
section.para: This manual complements several CentOS Studio documents. The "Installation Instructions" and "Getting Started Guide" provide basic information about obtaining and installing CentOS Studio and creating a basic CentOS system repository. The "System Definition File Reference" (SDFR) contains the syntax for system definition elements and attributes. Finally, CentOS Studio has a set of man pages explaining the centosstudio command, its options and the CentOS Studio configuration file, centosstudio.conf. This manual contains references to all four throughout the text.
These CentOS Studio documents are available at the CentOS Studio website.

section.title: How to Read
section.para: The intent of the manual is to help you use CentOS Studio effectively to build and maintain solutions, and to use solutions to install and update client machines. This manual takes a top-down approach, explaining the concepts before giving steps, commands and code examples that you can use to build, deploy and enhance your own system repositories.

section.title: Conventions Used
section.para: The document conventions are alphabetically listed below.

listitem.para: The Caution tag flags issues of importance.

caution.para: Using the 'dd' command to copy the diskboot.img file onto a USB key will destroy existing data on the device.

listitem.para: Command names in CentOS Studio or function names in other programs appear throughout the document.

Elements and attributes in XML are referred to by their XPath equivalents. The active node is always considered to be the root, system; thus, the first element in the XPath expression is the top-level element, while subsequent elements/attributes are its children. Top-level elements in the SDFR and their child elements use the parent/child/child format, while @attribute-names are preceded by an @ symbol. The assumed parent element is system. For more details on XPath syntax, see XML Path Language.

listitem.para: CentOS Studio variables are presented in monospace font preceded by a dollar sign, e.g. $ID. Variables outside the CentOS Studio realm appear in lowercase in monospace font preceded by a dollar sign, e.g. $releasever.

section.title: Organization
section.para: This manual contains five chapters, each with an increasing level of complexity and detail.

listitem.para: Chapter I, "Preface," provides information about how to use and read this manual. It also contains information on obtaining the CentOS Studio product.

Chapter 2, "Introduction" explains what a solution is, how CentOS Studio helps you build one in an efficient timely manner and the underlying architecture that makes this improved performance possible. The section also includes a "Glossary of Terms" explaining terms used within the CentOS Studio realm.

Chapter 3, "Building a System," covers the basic concepts for configuring the CentOS Studio build machine, defining and deploying a solution, running CentOS Studio and updating a solution. As a use case model, these sections will help you create a basic Samba server repository based on CentOS 5.

Chapter 4, "Creating a Production Environment," will help you set up a managed development and deployment environment using CentOS Studio as its cornerstone. It explains implementing the development - staging - production environment within the context of CentOS Studio. The Samba server solution you created in Part I will have new feature requirements to implement in Part II.

Chapter 4 also discusses how CentOS Studio makes your life easier as a system or build administrator. Versioning system files and utilizing an object-oriented model through the XInclude mechanism for the solution definitions are important usability features. Choosing the best location for storing and downloading a solution via the web is another key concept.

Chapter 5, "Doing More with CentOS Studio" will help you customize your solutions. It describes using kickstart files to automate client installations, and provides information on creating CD/DVD installation images.
